column5: The girlfriend, sister and I caught between 20-25 smallies this weekend but not one was in the 3-5 range. That is a honey hole to say the least.

Depends on the body of water too. Some lakes are fun because they have big numbers of 1.5-2lb fish to keep you busy. A couple weeks ago on Erie, I fished for 3 hours and only caught 7 fish...but nothing under 4 lbs and the best would have been a tick over 6lbs. That's great, just not for kids or the impatient. Oh, and I  was 2 or 3 kilometers from shore so obviously not for shore fisherman.
Psh - I can cast that far.
1lb test Berkley nanofil ???

My honey hole is fricken sweet!  25 bass is a bad day  But, it changes with water Conditions/flow etc. It's best in summer and fall  Summer is wicked for numbers, but fall is for the fatties.  Keep in mind when I say 25 is a bad day, that's on a 6-7 hour day. I've caught over 100 lotsa times but im down there with food, drinks, fire etc. I might fish 15 hours to get a 100 fish. Lotsa people shore fishing might only fish a few hours  Ask GBW, one day I was fishing tubes for the first time. We were chatting on the phone and im not sure on the number??? But I think I caught like 13 bass in maybe 15 casts lol  Damn I love that spot though!

Ask GBW, one day I was fishing tubes for the first time. We were chatting on the phone and im not sure on the number??? But I think I caught like 13 bass in maybe 15 casts lol Yeah my phone was non-stop that day with pic's coming in, lol!!
Yeah bud. The 25 was in about 2 hours. Gf and sister don't have the patience. So numbers ovef size. This was also before the storm.
I betcha it would hold some big fish come fall!
I'm also told I missed out. This spring with the water high I was told it was holding some monster walleye and muskie before the water temps warmed up.
Ughhh bummer  My spot gets wicked end of summer for pike too, then walleye in the fall. No wallies in summer though, just sauger

Hi Guys,  New to fishing in Ontario.  I'm looking to go Friday for bass in Zone 16 is the only zone that's open until Saturday.  I just bought the gear and licenses for my girlfriend and me, I thought it would be a good thing to do together as she's shown interest. I was hoping someone could suggest a spot where we're almost guaranteed to catch some Bass, we're looking to eat them as well. I want to get her hooked on it, she's quite the catch (pun intended).  Many thanks, Oliver
From shore?
From shore?   Yes Sir, if we really get into it, we'll look at getting a boat.
Guaranteed numbers would be nearly impossible to guarantee..especially from shore.  Only way I can say you can guarantee would be a private pond with no pressure.

Hello friend. My best bet I can tell you is to go to Heart lake in Brampton or island lake in Orangeville. Rent a boat from the conservation authorities and explore the lakes. The rental prices are reasonable and the fishing can be good with a little luck.  Have a good opening weekend.
Hello friend. My best bet I can tell you is to go to Heart lake in Brampton or island lake in Orangeville.  eating largies outta heart or island lake...passssssssss
2 outta 3 ain't bad.
she may have more fun perch or crappie fishing and those are much better eat's than bass in my eye's (and taste buds)
16 opens Saturday. You say you are fishing friday?  Or did I misread?
Bass is way better than crappie lol (joking)  Very hard to find crappie from shore though  I've eaten 2 bass in my life, no thanks ill pass

Bass is way better than crappie lol (joking)  Very hard to find crappie from shore though  I've eaten 2 bass in my life, no thanks ill pass  you haven't eaten the right ones then   the smallies we catch in lake huron are sweet like perch    but, zone 16 covers a LARGE area, more than can be covered in a day or two, windsor to scarborough,up to penatang,over to tobermory, which part are you interested in?, and bass season opens 4th saturday of june  theres lots of places in the bruce peninsula where you can catch bass from shore, and boat rentals are pretty cheap for tinner with a 9.9 on it
Some decent fish can be caught in the river systems, or from piers,  just depends on where you live.
Yeah, I know alot of people that will keep them on the deep, colder lakes
16 opens Saturday. You say you are fishing friday?  Or did I misread? Nope, we all read it the same hence why I said 'perch or crappie' as a target...

Hi Guys's,  Thank you for being so responsive, what a cool forum!!!  I accidentally put down zone 16 I meant 17!  Any suggestions for around Peterborough.  I have only eaten bass once, I caught it in Algonquin and it was delicious!  Many thanks, Z

Go see Will at Curtis Point Cottages (a member here) and tell him you heard of them from this site.  And rent a boat as long as you have a valid boaters card.  If not see if he or others can guide you two for a bit.

Go see Will at Curtis Point Cottages (a member here) and tell him you heard of them from this site.  And rent a boat as long as you have a valid boaters card.  If not see if he or others can guide you two for a bit.  need a card to a rent a 9.9 tinner now?
Yes, even a trolling motor counts.

need a card to a rent a 9.9 tinner now?   Yes, even a trolling motor counts. No, you don't need a card to rent a boat.  But the renter must walk you through a safety check list.  But if you own your own boat, you will need the boaters card even for an electric motor.  To the OP:  I think all of the lakes around Peterborough have bass in them.  The Otonabe river is another option.  There are no guarantees though; fishing doesn't work that way.

No, you don't need a card to rent a boat.  But the renter must walk you through a safety check list.  But if you own your own boat, you will need the boaters card even for an electric motor.     thats what i thought, even still, boaters cards are easy to get, just takes a lot of time invested since the online modules are timed now

A bit off topic, but I have never understood why the Gov't overseers would make me have to get a boaters card at 53 years old and basically 50 years of on the water boating experience, but a brand new person can rent a boat after 15 minutes of "safety instruction".  My boat is at Hindson in Penetang and there is a Diverse Rental there, so I see what goes on.  There are very inexperienced people renting their boats and heading out.  At least they tend to wear their life jackets.  As for bass, I won't eat a largemouth.  I find them a bit "muddy" tasting.  Not bad, just not good enough to kill a fish when there are other options.  I will eat smallmouth from Georgian Bay though, as long as it is in clean water and not in an area where they are too grubby.  On or two grubs I will cut out, but too many is just a bit "icky".  I wouldn't say they are as good as perch or walleye, but they are pretty good.  I also like to eat the odd pike.  About 3 to 5 lbs is a great size so the y-bones are larger and easier to avoid.  I don't cut them out, I leave em in and eat around them.  I think its a huge waste of a resource to kill a fish and then throw away 1/3 of it..  Larger and they all go back.

pops munches on the odd clearwater smallie outta gbay, says they taste no different than a perch. Cant say i dont believe him when all they eat are crawdads and shiners and basically never live near weeds.

Hi Guy's,  Well she's said she'll go again so that's a win.  Only caught a tiny small mouth, and a catfish of all things.  Any tips on getting bass in the 3-5lb range? Would a boat make a huge difference?  Thanks!

Hi Guy's,  Well she's said she'll go again so that's a win.  Only caught a tiny small mouth, and a catfish of all things.  Any tips on getting bass in the 3-5lb range? Would a boat make a huge difference?  Thanks!  a boat makes a huge difference and changes the game.  you can cover WAY more water than you ever could fishing from shore

Unless your lucky enough to have a honey hole, she's gonna be pretty hard to consistently find 3-5lb smallies from shore.  Even then 5lbers is not gonna happen often  If you ever find that spot, don't tell anyone lol
